Target: The Building Environment ontology (OntoBuiltEnv) is an ontology developed for representing key information about buildings. It combines information about building usage, key construction characteristics, location and address, and estimated property value. More detailed geometric information can be retrieved from the associated OntoCityGml representation.

Comment: A built structure with ground, roof, and walls which stands more or less permanently in one place.
Unique identifier describing the building.
Location of building footprint centroid in WGS84 coordinates.
An area defined for administrative purposes, e.g. a county or postal code district.
A relationship between a building and its address.
A relationship between an address and an encompassing administrative district.
A relationship between an address and the respective postal code.
A relationship between an address and the respective street name.
A relationship between an address and the respective property number (e.g. house and/or unit number)
A relationship between a building and an encompassing administrative district.
A relationship between a building and its corresponding instance IRI in OntoCityGml.
A relationship between a building and its total floor area.
A relationship between a building and its total installed photovoltaics area.
A relationship between a building and its ground elevation.
A relationship between a building and its (estimated) property value.
Key construction component of a building (i.e. wall, floor, roof, window).
A relationship between a building and one of its key construction components.
Key construction characteristics of the building's walls.
Key construction characteristics of the building's roof.
Key construction characteristics of the building's windows.
Key construction characteristics of the building's floor.
A relationship between a building and its construction dates.
A relationship between a building and its overall energy efficiency rating (e.g. linear 'A to G' rating (where A is the most energy efficient and G is the least energy efficient))
A relationship between a building and its total number of habitable rooms.
The built form of the property.
A property with a detached built form.
A property with a semi-detached built form.
A property with a terraced built form.
The general type of the property.
A dwelling that serves as living quarters for one or more families, with one or more storeys.
A small house with a single story.
Typically offsite manufactured bungalow-style homes that are located within a private estate.
A self-contained apartment (usually on two floors) in a larger building and with its own entrance from the outside.
Description of the (intended) usage and/or function of a building.
A building that serves as living space for one or more parties.
A building that serves non-living purposes (i.e. commercial, industrial, public buildings).
A building that serves as living space for one party.
A building that serves as living space for more than one party.
Emergency services are organizations which ensure public safety and health by addressing different emergencies.
Medical care includes sites which focus on the provision of secondary medical care services.
Education includes a very broad group of sites with a common high level primary function of providing education (either state funded or by fees).
A place of business where professional or clerical duties are performed.
A feature that sells to the general public finished goods.
A place where members of a religious group congregate for worship.
A building used for industrial fabrication or processing of goods.
A business whose primary function is the serving of food for consumption on the premises.
A business whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
A building where travelers can pay for lodging and meals and other services.
A feature where one or many different sports can be played.
A feature that is deemed to be of particular interest to society.
A feature that is associated with the movement of passengers and goods.
A facility which may house fire fighters, and contains the equipment and vehicles.
The local office of a police force in a particular area.
A medical facility that provides second level care.
A medical facility for outpatient primary level healthcare.
A building where young people receive primary and secondary education.
A site providing higher/university education.
